items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels have receded overnight on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck, though the level of Derwent Water remains high following the heavy rainfall on Saturday. There is likely to be a similar response to further rainfall through this morning (Sunday 13/02/22). Areas most at risk include the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. No property flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast and amend this message if necessary. Our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Monday morning (14/02/2022), or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River levels are rising on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to heavy rainfall and further rainfall is expected for several hours today, Sunday 13/02/22. Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. With some further rainfall forecast tomorrow, Monday 14/02/22, river and lake levels are expected to remain high for the next few days but we do not expect flooding to properties. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 21:00 today, 13/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.1m to 3.5m overnight, 13/02/2022.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 14/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of riverside areas is expected tonight, Sunday 13/2/22.  The current upstream level at Westwick Weir is 1.0m, and is expected to reach 1.6m in the early hours of Monday, several hours before levels peak. The area most at risk is around Roecliffe Caravan Park.  We expect river levels to remain high into Monday 14/02/22.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking and operating local defences as required.  Please stay away from fast moving water, and do not walk or drive through floodwater.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: The flood Alert for the Lower Ure has been issued due to rising river levels in the lower catchment, as a result of rainfall over the weekend.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Some further rainfall is expected overnight, which may keep levels high through Monday, 14/02/22. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from 21:00 today, 13/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 1.8m to 2.1m overnight 13/02/22.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 14/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert has been issued as river levels are rising following recent rainfall in the Yorkshire Dales. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected from around 08:00 on Monday morning 14/02/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads and riverside foot and cycle paths. We expect levels on the River Ouse to rise through Monday and to peak overnight into Tuesday. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and checking and operating defences as required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads or carparks near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Monday morning or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as conditions have eased and tides have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels have receded overnight following the heavy rainfall yesterday on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck but may rise again in a similar response to rainfall throughout this morning (Sunday 13/02/2022). Flooding is forecast to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. We do not expect to be issuing any Flood Warnings and property flooding is not expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwentwater is still rising albeit slowly as a result of further heavy rainfall during this morning. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the the lake frontage areas of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is not forecast over the rest of tonight and we expect levels on Derwentwater to flatten off around Midnight but remain high through into Monday morning, 14/02/22. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising closely with Keswick Campsite Management as the Lodore Lake Level Gauge has developed a fault which we are seeking to rectify as soon as possible tomorrow.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated on Monday (14/02/2022), or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this afternoon (Sunday 13/02/2022).
Overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Dart area. This has meant that the River Dart is now rising.
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised flooding to low lying land and roads from 11:30 today.
We expect the river to remain high throughout the afternoon with further rainfall expected this afternoon, followed by showers over the next 24 hours.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Monday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible during Sunday afternoon 13/02/2022. Heavy rainfall this morning and overnight in the River Erme and River Avon areas is causing river levels to rise.
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside low lying land and roads flooding from 2pm on Sunday afternoon.
We expect the river to remain high throughout Sunday afternoon with further scattered showers expected into Monday.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Monday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels are rising at the Chetnole river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 13/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.  We expect river levels to begin falling later this evening, 13/02/22. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Monday, 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the situation.   Please avoid contact with any remaining flood water.  "

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to todays rainfall.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride from 05:15 PM on 13/02/2022.
No further rainfall is forecast for this evening.
River levels will start to fall overnight, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads remains.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Chiselborough river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 13/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.   We expect river levels to begin falling later this evening, 13/02/22. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Monday, 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are now falling on the River Wey near Passfield Mill, Liphook, but are rising at Godalming and Tilford, as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday. 
The forecast for today, 14th Feb, is for lighter patchy rain. 
We are closely monitoring the situation, and our operatives will be out today clearing trash screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been issued due to rainfall on the Pennines over the weekend. Levels will rise overnight in the lower Nidd tonight, Sunday 13/02/22 and may reach alert levels on Monday morning. Flooding of low lying land and footpaths is possible. Areas most at risk are land around the Hunsingore area. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 14/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is rising and already high in places. Almost half a month's rainfall (30mm) has been recorded in Liss today (Sunday 13/02/2022). From 02:00 14/02/2022, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties, including on Station Road next to the railway, Liss and Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet. From 06:00 14/02/2022, flooding could also affect gardens in Iping, Stedham and Midhurst. From 10:00 14/02/2022, flood water could affect fields, gardens, rural roads and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham and fields near Fittleworth Mill. Rain will clear at 02:00 on 14/02/2022, to leave a largely dry Monday. The river should begin to fall in Liss by 08:00 14/02/2022, returning to normal by Monday evening. Near Fittleworth, the Western Rother will stay high until Tuesday. Peak water levels could end up similar to those on Boxing Day 2021. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 on 14/02/2022.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from approximately 08:00 today, 14/02/2022 at Kinnersley Manor, and is also possible along the River Mole as far as Cobham.  We expect flooding to affect land and roads. Property flooding is not currently expected.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 18:00, 14/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
